title: 105_s2207
content: The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" aims to empower the Attorney General to prevent mergers that would harm competition in the telecommunications industry if certain competition-enhancing requirements are not met. It amends the Clayton Act to address restraints of trade in telecommunications. The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" defines a large local telephone company as one serving more than 5% of telephone access lines in the US. It prohibits mergers or acquisitions of such companies unless approved by the Attorney General to promote competition in the telecommunications industry. The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" prohibits mergers or acquisitions of large local telephone companies unless approved by the Attorney General and the FCC, ensuring competition and compliance with telecommunications regulations. The Communications Act of 1934 requires compliance with regulations from the Commission and States. The Attorney General must report findings on mergers' impact on competition in the telecommunications industry to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees within 10 days. The Communications Act of 1934 mandates compliance with regulations from the Commission and States. The Attorney General must report on mergers' impact on competition in the telecommunications industry to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees within 10 days. Large local telephone companies proposing mergers or acquisitions must file applications with the Attorney General and the Federal Communications Commission simultaneously. The decision on the application must be issued within the applicable review period. The Communications Commission must issue a decision on mergers within the specified time frame. The district courts have jurisdiction to prevent mergers inconsistent with findings under subsection (b). The Attorney General can initiate legal proceedings in any district court. The district courts have jurisdiction to prevent mergers that do not meet specified conditions. The Attorney General or the Federal Communications Commission can initiate legal proceedings for such cases. The district courts have jurisdiction to prevent mergers that do not meet specified conditions, with the Attorney General or the Federal Communications Commission able to initiate legal proceedings in such cases. If parties involved in a merger or acquisition do not meet the requirements specified, action can be taken. SEC. 4. PRESERVATION OF EXISTING AUTHORITIES. This Act does not affect antitrust laws or FCC authority under the Communications Act of 1934 regarding mergers of large incumbent local exchange carriers. Antitrust laws are defined as in the Clayton Act. SEC. 5. APPLICABILITY. This Act applies to mergers or acquisitions of controlling interests in large local telephone companies after the enactment date.
